text: <@U013ZLJARC7> Nice examples, thanks! My working habits are quite similar, also centered around Emacs. But I wonder which substrate (libraries, ...) you used for the video scrubber. I find myself having to do such work as well now with the Covid-related shift to videos, but none of the video editing tools I found so far are scriptable to the extent that you demonstrate.

elements.text: Nice examples, thanks! My working habits are quite similar, also centered around Emacs. But I wonder which substrate (libraries, ...) you used for the video scrubber. I find myself having to do such work as well now with the Covid-related shift to videos, but none of the video editing tools I found so far are scriptable to the extent that you demonstrate.

text: <@UJBAJNFLK> I was surprised to find recently that Davinci Resolve is free; and competitive with the Adobe and Apple Offerings.  It's not hard to learn, and does all the video editing tasks you are likely to need. Needs a reasonably beefy machine in my experience.  Not a coding solution, but off all the editors I've tried, it's the one that works best in my experience.

text:
<@UJBAJNFLK> I used a pile of my own stuff, which is one of the reasons it took so little time and effort to make. That said, I think you could get a great deal of mileage out of `#lang video`:
<https://docs.racket-lang.org/video@video/index.html>

elements.text: I used a pile of my own stuff, which is one of the reasons it took so little time and effort to make. That said, I think you could get a great deal of mileage out of

text:
"I'd rather cut myself than write and maintain another piece of ad-hoc software for myself."

<https://magnusson.io/post/backups|https://magnusson.io/post/backups>

elements.text: "I'd rather cut myself than write and maintain another piece of ad-hoc software for myself."

text:
I think the distinction is that the self-written software there is not something that produces a result. He's talking about trying to automate something that he can then forget about and rely on.

That's completely different to cobbling something together that gives you active superpowers right now, for something that you can see or check worked.

elements.text:
I think the distinction is that the self-written software there is not something that produces a result. He's talking about trying to automate something that he can then forget about and rely on.

That's completely different to cobbling something together that gives you active superpowers right now, for something that you can see or check worked.

text: True of the article in general, but this particular quote popped out at me for how much broader it was phrased.
